segments.text: And she sees the struggle of our times as a struggle for survival and whether we're going to go on to become that kind of grand human species implicit in what we already are.
It's interesting to those, I'm sure, people who've had similar experiences who've taught the book, what students' responses are to a work like Starmaker.
What typically
What I get when I teach it, first of all, there's a lot of moaning and groaning.
I warn people about it.
I say, you know, this is a very difficult work.
It makes tremendous demands on your imagination.
I can only read about 15 or 20 pages of Star Maker at a time.
I just start getting dizzy from the demands that the book makes on me.
So one, you've got to read this slow.
You've got to take your time.
You have to think about it.
So you get a lot of complaints.
Why did you sign this book?
It's so...
long, it's so slow, there's no plot, there are no characters, et cetera, et cetera, et cetera.
And then every year that I've taught that book, I also have, right away, there's a small minority that get very excited about the book.
gradually more people have won over.

And I find later on, months later, and sometimes years later, when it's not a matter of currying favor to get a good grade, years later, people come back to see me and say, you remember that book by Stapleton that you assigned, Star Maker?
I've never read anything like that.
That book changed my life.
It changed the whole way I look at myself and human beings and where we are, what we are, and so on.
That book changed my life.
Well, how many people who've taught paradise laws have had a response like that from the students?
As I say, our job is critical.
We scholars and critics of science fiction may help make the choice, and it is a critical distinction.
It is helping to make a choice.
between the values of the futures exchange and the values of, say, the space merchants, between starship troopers and the forever war.
Our scholarship and criticism may, in fact, have an influence on the future that the human race chooses to create.
Thank you, Bruce.
That was a very good speech.
And let me personally thank you, not thank you, but congratulate you on winning this award, a well-deserved, well-merited award winner for our distinguished list of pilgrims.
Before we leave, I want to discuss just one small matter for a couple of minutes.
I wish I would have had the opportunity today to thank another set of guests that we invited, but unfortunately they could not come, and these were the guests from the Soviet Union.
I'd ask for the Strogatzky brothers, of course.
We met Boris in Leningrad last year, and I had high hopes that, since a number of science fiction people had gone through, that
the writers' union houses there that they might reciprocate.

And also, that was a means to pry loose another distinguished Pilgrim winner, a world specialist, Julius Kargaletsky, one of our early Pilgrim winners, who was set to come to pick up his award at Penn State, I believe, wasn't it?
Was that 1972?
Around in there?
And at the last moment was sent to Stockholm, I believe, or someplace like that.
And I was hoping this time he could get here and we could give him a belated observance for his winning.
But he could not come.
As a euphemism, they say he has family troubles.
A member of his family apparently is in disfavor and that is reflected, of course, on him.
So I'm sorry that our Russian science fiction writers and critics and editors did not show up.
Since some of us were written up in Pravda last December, I had high hopes that they would show up.
But that was not the case.
And so since I can't thank them for coming, I will say that I am sorry they couldn't be here.
And perhaps sometime in the future,
the Soviet government may allow us to finally present our wayward pilgrim.
Thank you very much, and have a good time at the rest of the meeting.
